citations.narrative:
The licensee is currently authorized for a maximum number of 50 animals on hand at any single point in time during the
period of licensure. Counting all regulated animals currently on the property or inventory, the total inventory is 54.
Licenses are approved based on the numbers and types of animals a facility can properly manage. If a facility plans to
exceed its approved maximum number of animals, they are required to obtain a new license before any change that
results in more than the authorized number of animals. The licensee needs to maintain the authorized number of animals
or apply for a new license to account for the increase.
Correct by July 28, 2023

The outdoor area of a sheltered housing facility containing two ring-tailed lemurs is not completely enclosed by a
perimeter fence. The outdoor area of the enclosure has wire panel walls and roof, beyond which there is some additional
fencing of various heights. However, there is not one continuous 6 feet tall perimeter fence. A perimeter fence is essential
for restricting contact between exotic animals and unauthorized people or animals. A perimeter fence also acts as a
secondary containment system in the event an animal escapes from its primary enclosure. The licensee must provide a
perimeter fence that is of sufficient height, as required by this section, to protect the animals in the facility and keep
unwanted species out.
Correct by July 28, 2023

The primary enclosures containing two artic foxes, one serval and one Eurasian lynx is not completely enclosed by a
perimeter fence. Around the primary enclosures there is some additional fencing of various heights. However, there is not
one continuous 6 feet tall perimeter fence around the primary enclosures. A perimeter fence is essential for restricting
contact between exotic animals and unauthorized people or animals. A perimeter fence also acts as a secondary
containment system in the event an animal escapes from its primary enclosure. The licensee must provide a perimeter
fence that is of sufficient height, as required by this section, to protect the animals in the facility and keep unwanted
species out.
Correct by July 28, 2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.1(b)(2)(i) 
   
Requirements and application 
The licensee is currently authorized for a maximum number of 50 animals on hand at any single point in time during the 
period of licensure. Counting all regulated animals currently on the property or inventory, the total inventory is 54. 
Licenses are approved based on the numbers and types of animals a facility can properly manage. If a facility plans to 
exceed its approved maximum number of animals, they are required to obtain a new license before any change that 
results in more than the authorized number of animals. The licensee needs to maintain the authorized number of animals 
or apply for a new license to account for the increase. 
Correct by July 28, 2023 
3.77(f) 
   
Sheltered housing facilities. 
The outdoor area of a sheltered housing facility containing two ring-tailed lemurs is not completely enclosed by a 
perimeter fence. The outdoor area of the enclosure has wire panel walls and roof, beyond which there is some additional 
fencing of various heights. However, there is not one continuous 6 feet tall perimeter fence. A perimeter fence is essential 
for restricting contact between exotic animals and unauthorized people or animals. A perimeter fence also acts as a 
secondary containment system in the event an animal escapes from its primary enclosure. The licensee must provide a

perimeter fence that is of sufficient height, as required by this section, to protect the animals in the facility and keep 
unwanted species out.  
Correct by July 28, 2023 
3.127(d) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
The primary enclosures containing two artic foxes, one serval and one Eurasian lynx is not completely enclosed by a 
perimeter fence. Around the primary enclosures there is some additional fencing of various heights. However, there is not 
one continuous 6 feet tall perimeter fence around the primary enclosures. A perimeter fence is essential for restricting 
contact between exotic animals and unauthorized people or animals. A perimeter fence also acts as a secondary 
containment system in the event an animal escapes from its primary enclosure.  The licensee must provide a perimeter 
fence that is of sufficient height, as required by this section, to protect the animals in the facility and keep unwanted 
species out. 
Correct by July 28, 2023 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
